awd_titl_txt: Invariant Objects and Their Connections in Dynamical Systems: Rigorous Results, Computations, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Many systems in nature are governed by deterministic rules. Nevertheless, the results of applying even simple rules many times may be complicated and hard to understand (think of a simple motion of a spoon in a cup of coffee; after a few repetitions the liquid is completely scrambled). It is well known that small disturbances can have rapid growth, as for example in the "butterfly effect" in meteorology.  Other systems where complicated effects take place include the motions of small celestial bodies subject to the changing forces of the sun and the planets. In some cases (for example, in the motion of satellites) it is of interest to devise maneuvers that take advantage of the natural amplification of disturbances to accomplish big effects with small efforts. To understand such complicated behavior, this research project searches for pieces that move in an orderly way and that act as anchors and reference points for all the other motions. This allows systematic classification of the possible motions. 

To accomplish these goals, this project will employ methods from several parts of mathematics. The fact that an object behaves simply can be formulated as a functional equation that can be studied with rigorous mathematics using functional analysis and topology. One surprise in these studies is that delicate number-theoretic properties (for instance whether a frequency satisfies a polynomial equation with integer coefficients) play a practical role. The tools from functional analysis must be supplemented by a very strong geometric intuition. The project also aims to develop practical algorithms for calculation, so that the knowledge acquired in the theory can be made concrete. The mixture of tools (analysis, topology, geometry, and numerical algorithms) makes involvement in the project an effective training ground for students who can subsequently pursue either academic or industrial careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the project was to develop a broad approach to finding   
landmarks in phase space. These landmarks can be used as harbors
so that jumping among them can generate large motions even with
small perturbing forces.


The approach uses different methods: rigorous mathematical analysis and
computation so that they reinforce each other.
There are several landmarks considered: periodic orbits, whiskered tori,
normally hyperbolic manifolds and their stable and unstable manifolds.

In each of the cases, we developed rigorous constructive theorems of
existence, developed efficient numerical methods and applied them to some
models of interest.  The models considered are also rather varied.
They included models in celestial mechanics as well as models in infinite dimensions
such as models of electrodynamics.


Many models of celestial mechanics involve weak frictions (usually due
to tidal effects). In the solar system, these effects are very small and
have negligible effect over the study of motions over a few thousand years.
On the other hand are a dominant effect over billion of years. For example
the tidal forces in the moon can be ignored in a moon shot, but they
become crucial to explain why the moon shows only one face to the earth.
Adding a small amount of friction is a singular perturbstion.
No matter how small the perturbation is, the long term behavior is
drastically affected.

 

We developed a very delicate theory of the existence of quasiperiodic
orbits in systems with a small friction. There were mathematical surprises
we discovered that the solutions have a very
unexpected  domain of analyticity and that the asymptotic expansions have
a fixed rate of growth.
The accuracy of the expansions first increases with the order, but
expanding to a very high order leads to nonsensical predictions. The rigorous
results allow to know the order that gives the most accuracy.
We developed very efficient numerical algorithms (low storage requirements,
low operation count) for quasi-periodic orbits and implemented them in
a concrete model of astronomical interest (spin-orbit problem).
We showed that the combination of efficient methods and rigorous analysis
can lead to accurate and reliable results. Our analysis gave
also a  quantitative clarification of  the procedure of averaging the friction
which was discussed in the literature.

Many mechanical machines have the
design goal of eliminating friction.  We have
collaborated in the study of vibrations with small friction with mechanical engineers.
More than a century ago,  Lyapunov discovered families of
periodic orbits in frictionless systems.
Adding  friction,
individual  periodic orbits disappear but the the region occupied
by the family becomes a  path towards  equilibrium which organizes
many orbits.

 

Another singular perturbation considered
was introducing delays in the equation.
If one considers the time that gravitational signals
take to propagate among planets, the forces among planets
should be a function not of the positions at the same time but at
a  previous time (the time taken by the  signal from one to another).
This problem is mathematically very complicated. Indeed there
is no complete general theory of existence/uniqueness/smooth
dependence for all initial conditions. (Even  the question of
what is the appropriate set of initial conditions is  debated).
We systematically  obtained families of exact solutions which
give a catalogue of possibilities that can match many physical situations.



The mixture of rigorous analysis, numerical exploration and connection
with concrete problems has proved to be very attractive to students and postdocs.
Besides the intellectual stimulation
it enhances opportunities both in academia and
in industry (industry is becoming increasingly attractive
to students since the successive postdocs are becoming
hard for personal life and tenured academic positions are becoming scarcer
and involve  administrative tasks).
Hence, the grant has attracted a large number of
graduate students and postdocs, many of them brought other sources
of funding.  One of the graduate students was
awarded an NSF postdoctoral fellowship and we received another
NSF postdoc.

 


Since the research  produces surprising effects in easy to implement
mechanical systems, it is ideal for popular
presentations that encourage careful thinking about the
world and taking  an experimental approach. We have participated
in many science fairs, been interviewed in podcasts, written popular expositions.
This allows meeting  people who are considering science,
give them encouragement and have personal discussions.


One of the challenges of the last years has been to develop methods
to connect remotely. We have put some effort into developing remote activities
and make them more active. Some lectures by members of the grant  are already in YouTube.
 Classes online
seem
 to be effective in improving the GPA, but more thought and
experiments are needed on  personal interaction
and encouragement of new people in science. There are many opportunities
if the right approach is found.
